articles.headline: U.S. to Announce New Tariffs on Chinese Electric Vehicles
articles.snippet: The administration could raise tariffs on electric vehicles from China to 100 percent in an attempt to protect American auto manufacturers.
articles.abstract: The administration could raise tariffs on electric vehicles from China to 100 percent in an attempt to protect American auto manufacturers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is set to announce new tariffs as high as 100 percent on Chinese electric vehicles and additional import taxes on other Chinese goods, including semiconductors, as early as next week, according to people familiar with the matter.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Apple Will Revamp Siri to Catch Up to Its Chatbot Competitors
articles.snippet: Apple plans to announce that it will bring generative A.I. to iPhones after the company’s most significant reorganization in a decade.
articles.abstract: Apple plans to announce that it will bring generative A.I. to iPhones after the company’s most significant reorganization in a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple’s top software executives decided early last year that Siri, the company’s virtual assistant, needed a brain transplant.
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle, Brian X. Chen and Cade Metz

articles.headline: Jim Simons, Math Genius Who Conquered Wall Street, Dies at 86
articles.snippet: Using advanced computers, he went from M.I.T. professor to multibillionaire. His Medallion fund had 66 percent average annual returns for decades.
articles.abstract: Using advanced computers, he went from M.I.T. professor to multibillionaire. His Medallion fund had 66 percent average annual returns for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jim Simons, the prizewinning mathematician who abandoned a stellar academic career, then plunged into finance — a world he knew nothing about — and became one of the most successful Wall Street investors ever, died on Friday in his home in Manhattan. He was 86.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Kandell

articles.headline: U.S. Criticizes Israel for Failure to Protect Civilians in the Gaza Conflict
articles.snippet: In a report, the State Department avoids sweeping conclusions but raises the prospect that Israel may have violated humanitarian laws.
articles.abstract: In a report, the State Department avoids sweeping conclusions but raises the prospect that Israel may have violated humanitarian laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration believes that Israel has most likely violated international standards in failing to protect civilians in Gaza but has not found specific instances that would justify the withholding of military aid, the State Department told Congress on Friday.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley

articles.headline: The ‘Betches’ Got Rich. So What’s Next?
articles.snippet: The women’s media company, which started as a raunchy college blog, is a rare financial success story — and on the White House’s radar. Now, it’s wrestling with how to grow up alongside its readers.
articles.abstract: The women’s media company, which started as a raunchy college blog, is a rare financial success story — and on the White House’s radar. Now, it’s wrestling with how to grow up alongside its readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a cold February morning, Betches Media, the millennial and Gen Z women’s humor company best known for its Instagram memes, was celebrating its 13th birthday, which its three co-founders had gleefully named its “betch mitzvah.”
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Farewell, Chuck E. Cheese Animatronic Band
articles.snippet: A mainstay of the pizza and arcade chain, by turns endearing and creepy, will be phased out by year’s end at all but two locations. We visited one of them.
articles.abstract: A mainstay of the pizza and arcade chain, by turns endearing and creepy, will be phased out by year’s end at all but two locations. We visited one of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Munch’s Make Believe Band at Chuck E. Cheese has performed for countless birthdays, end-of-season Little League parties and other celebrations. There’s been Chuck E. Cheese and Helen Henny on vocals, Mr. Munch on keys, Jasper T. Jowls on guitar, and Pasqually on drums.
articles.byline: By Jesus Jiménez and Jackie Molloy

articles.headline: The Long, Tortured Road to Biden’s Clash With Netanyahu Over Gaza War
articles.snippet: The president offered strong support to Israel after Oct. 7 but has grown increasingly frustrated over the conduct of the war. “He has just gotten to a point where enough is enough,” a friend says.
articles.abstract: The president offered strong support to Israel after Oct. 7 but has grown increasingly frustrated over the conduct of the war. “He has just gotten to a point where enough is enough,” a friend says.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden laid it out for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel long before letting the public know. In a conversation bristling with tension on Feb. 11, the president warned the prime minister against a major assault on the Gaza city of Rafah — and suggested that continued U.S. support would depend on how Israel proceeded.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker

articles.headline: Trump May Owe $100 Million From Double-Dip Tax Breaks, Audit Shows
articles.snippet: A previously unknown focus of an I.R.S. audit is a dubious accounting maneuver that effectively meant taking the same write-offs twice on a Chicago skyscraper.
articles.abstract: A previously unknown focus of an I.R.S. audit is a dubious accounting maneuver that effectively meant taking the same write-offs twice on a Chicago skyscraper.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump used a dubious accounting maneuver to claim improper tax breaks from his troubled Chicago tower, according to an Internal Revenue Service inquiry uncovered by The New York Times and ProPublica. Losing a yearslong audit battle over the claim could mean a tax bill of more than $100 million.
articles.byline: By Russ Buettner and Paul Kiel

articles.headline: Yahya Sinwar Helped Start the War in Gaza. Now He’s Key to Its Endgame.
articles.snippet: Hamas’s leader in Gaza is considered an architect of the Oct. 7 attacks that prompted Israel to retaliate. As mediators seek a cease-fire, a deal depends on Mr. Sinwar as well as his Israeli foes.
articles.abstract: Hamas’s leader in Gaza is considered an architect of the Oct. 7 attacks that prompted Israel to retaliate. As mediators seek a cease-fire, a deal depends on Mr. Sinwar as well as his Israeli foes.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Hamas attacked Israel in October, igniting the war in Gaza, Israeli leaders described the group’s most senior official in the territory, Yahya Sinwar, as a “dead man walking.” Considering him an architect of the raid, Israel has portrayed Mr. Sinwar’s assassination as a major goal of its devastating counterattack.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Rasgon

articles.headline: Elon Musk’s Diplomacy: Woo Right-Wing World Leaders. Then Benefit.
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk has built a constellation of like-minded heads of state — including Argentina’s Javier Milei and India’s Narendra Modi — to push his own politics and expand his business empire.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk has built a constellation of like-minded heads of state — including Argentina’s Javier Milei and India’s Narendra Modi — to push his own politics and expand his business empire.
articles.lead_paragraph: Minutes after it became clear that Javier Milei had been elected president of South America’s second-largest nation in November, Elon Musk posted on X: “Prosperity is ahead for Argentina.”
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac, Jack Nicas and Alex Travelli

articles.headline: Frustrated by Gaza Coverage, Student Protesters Turn to Al Jazeera
articles.snippet: Students active in campus protests value Al Jazeera’s on-the-ground coverage and its perspective on the Israel-Hamas war. They draw distinctions between it and major American outlets.
articles.abstract: Students active in campus protests value Al Jazeera’s on-the-ground coverage and its perspective on the Israel-Hamas war. They draw distinctions between it and major American outlets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nick Wilson has closely followed news on the war in Gaza since October. But Mr. Wilson, a Cornell student, is picky when it comes to his media diet: As a pro-Palestinian activist, he doesn’t trust major American outlets’ reporting on Israel’s campaign in Gaza.
articles.byline: By Santul Nerkar

articles.headline: Russian Forces Push Deeper Into Northern Ukraine
articles.snippet: With Ukrainian troops outnumbered, exhausted and now in retreat near Kharkiv, many Ukrainians wonder if the war has taken a significant turn for the worse.
articles.abstract: With Ukrainian troops outnumbered, exhausted and now in retreat near Kharkiv, many Ukrainians wonder if the war has taken a significant turn for the worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the past three days, Russian troops, backed by fighter jets, artillery and lethal drones, have poured across Ukraine’s northeastern border and seized at least nine villages and settlements, ­and more square miles per day than at almost any other point in the war, save the very beginning.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Constant Méheut

articles.headline: Gov. Jim Justice Faces Heavy Business Debts as He Seeks Senate Seat
articles.snippet: The Justice companies have long had a reputation for not paying their debts. But that may be catching up to them.
articles.abstract: The Justice companies have long had a reputation for not paying their debts. But that may be catching up to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jim Justice, the businessman-turned-politician governor of West Virginia, has been pursued in court for years by banks, governments, business partners and former employees for millions of dollars in unmet obligations.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Maureen Farrell

articles.headline: China Is Raising Bullet Train Fares as Debts and Costs Balloon
articles.snippet: The politically fraught move comes as part of a broader push in China to stem losses at subsidized public services.
articles.abstract: The politically fraught move comes as part of a broader push in China to stem losses at subsidized public services.
articles.lead_paragraph: China is taking the rare step of sharply increasing fares for riders on four major bullet train lines, in its broadest move to address rising costs and heavy debts since construction of the system began nearly two decades ago.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: A Night to Remember at the Opera, Complete With a Phantom
articles.snippet: About 130 children took part in a sleepover at Rome’s opera house, part of a campaign to make up for a lack of music education by making the theater and the art form more familiar and accessible.
articles.abstract: About 130 children took part in a sleepover at Rome’s opera house, part of a campaign to make up for a lack of music education by making the theater and the art form more familiar and accessible.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the pitch-dark auditorium of Rome’s Teatro Costanzi, a high-pitched lament floated from the top galleries. Dozens of flashlights snapped on, their beams crisscrossing crazily, seeking the source of the sound.
articles.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Alessandro Penso

articles.headline: Trump Leads in 5 Key States, as Young and Nonwhite Voters Express Discontent With Biden
articles.snippet: A new set of Times/Siena polls, including one with The Philadelphia Inquirer, reveal an erosion of support for the president among young and nonwhite voters upset about the economy and Gaza.
articles.abstract: A new set of Times/Siena polls, including one with The Philadelphia Inquirer, reveal an erosion of support for the president among young and nonwhite voters upset about the economy and Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump leads President Biden in five crucial battleground states, a new set of polls shows, as a yearning for change and discontent over the economy and the war in Gaza among young, Black and Hispanic voters threaten to unravel the president’s Democratic coalition.
articles.byline: By Nate Cohn

articles.headline: Priced Out of Housing, Communities Take Development Into Their Own Hands
articles.snippet: Across the country, neighborhood groups are uniting to fund mixed-use developments that meet housing and business demands, giving locals a place to live, work and learn new skills.
articles.abstract: Across the country, neighborhood groups are uniting to fund mixed-use developments that meet housing and business demands, giving locals a place to live, work and learn new skills.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the owner of the coffee retailer Higher Grounds Trading Company, Chris Treter had a problem: Business was booming, but his new hires couldn’t find affordable places to live.
articles.byline: By Keith Schneider

articles.headline: On Instagram, a Jewelry Ad Draws Solicitations for Sex With a 5-Year-Old
articles.snippet: Advertisers of merchandise for young girls find that adult men can become their unintended audience. In a test ad, convicted sex offenders inquired about a child model.
articles.abstract: Advertisers of merchandise for young girls find that adult men can become their unintended audience. In a test ad, convicted sex offenders inquired about a child model.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a children’s jewelry maker began advertising on Instagram, she promoted photos of a 5-year-old girl wearing a sparkly charm to users interested in parenting, children, ballet and other topics identified by Meta as appealing mostly to women.
articles.byline: By Michael H. Keller and Jennifer Valentino-DeVries

articles.headline: Secret Hamas Files Show How It Spied on Everyday Palestinians
articles.snippet: Hamas monitored political activity, online posts, and apparently even love lives. Palestinians were stuck between an Israeli blockade and a repressive security force.
articles.abstract: Hamas monitored political activity, online posts, and apparently even love lives. Palestinians were stuck between an Israeli blockade and a repressive security force.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar has for years overseen a secret police force in Gaza that conducted surveillance on everyday Palestinians and built files on young people, journalists and those who questioned the government, according to intelligence officials and a trove of internal documents reviewed by The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Adam Rasgon and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Exclusion of Jewish Jurors Prompts Review of California Death Row Cases
articles.snippet: Dozens of cases are under review after notes from jury selection in a 1990s murder case indicated that prosecutors worked to exclude Jews.
articles.abstract: Dozens of cases are under review after notes from jury selection in a 1990s murder case indicated that prosecutors worked to exclude Jews.
articles.lead_paragraph: A jury was being chosen for a murder trial nearly three decades ago in California. The state was seeking a death sentence for Ernest Dykes, who had been charged with killing a 9-year-old boy during a robbery in Oakland.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango
